body.p: Mary Russell Mitford submitted Charles the First, An Historial Tragedy, in Five Acts to the Examiner of Plays for review in 1825. The play was refused a license at that time, and so did not reach the stage until its production at the Victoria Theatre in 1834. London publisher John Duncombe and Co. produced the first printed edition in 1834. Philadelphia publishers Carey & Hart, Hogan & Thompson, and W. Marshall and Co., published an American edition the following year, in 1835, as part of the series Alexander's Modern Acting Drama: Consisting of the Most Popular Plays Produced at the Philadelphia Theatres and Elsewhere. The play was also published in the 1880s by J. Dicks in the cheap reprint series Dicks' Standard Plays. The play was collected in 1841 by Philadelphia publisher James Crissy in The Works of Mary Russell Mitford: Prose and Verse. The play was also included an authorized collection, The Dramatic Works of Mary Russell Mitford in 1854 by London publisher Hurst and Blackett.

In the 1830s, before publishing the full-length play, Mitfordpublished several selections from her tragedy in literary annuals, including the Forget Me Not, the Royal Lady's Magazine and the Metropolitan Magazine. An excerpt from the play was also included in the 1889 McGuffey's High School and Literary Reader as "The Trial of Charles the First" 230-237.

Also, parenthetical citations in the text will, on mouseover, bring up the usual blue popup notes that reference the Site Index. You may also tag within the flow of your sentences titles like Hamlet with the title element and the usual @ref attribute any other books you just want to mention inline, and these will output on the web with mouseover popups that pull info from the site index.
When to include editorial notes in your headnote. Use the note element sparingly in your headnote, and only when you wish to make an extended commentary on something that doesn't quite fit in the substance of the paragraph you are writing, like perhaps so.The Digital Mitford team has tried to limit the usage of the note element as a matter of editorial policy, since we have a standardized and centralized referencing system with the site index. For that reason there are likely to be fewer things called "notes" (or coded with the element note) in our project files.
